name: 2-(trimethylsilyl)-3a,4,5,6,7,7a-hexahydro-1H-inden-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2430

name: 2-(trimethylsilyl)-3a,4,5,6,7,7a-hexahydro-1H-inden-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2430
Reason: The basic structure of the target compound includes an indanone core, which would be somewhat similar to indan whose melting point is around 13 degrees Celsius or 56 degrees Fahrenheit. The oxygen in the ketone functional group will engage in dipole-dipole interactions and slightly increase the melting point. However, the introduction of the trimethylsilyl group at the 2-position is expected to significantly affect the properties due to the size and the inductive effect of the silicon attached to three methyl groups. While silicon is less electronegative than carbon, it does have a larger atomic radius which would increase the van der Waals interactions marginally, but it can also increase the steric hindrance which might slightly lower the melting point due to a disruption of crystal lattice formation. The combined effect of these functional groups may still result in a net increase. Therefore, we estimate: Ketone: +20 for the dipoles interactions, Trimethylsilyl: +20 for the increased van der Waals interactions minus 10 for the increased steric hindrance.
